description: A 1,600-year-old architectural marvel that has served as an Orthodox cathedral, Ottoman mosque, secular museum, and now a mosque again. Built in the 6th century during the Byzantine Empire, it features a massive dome, stunning mosaics, and layers of history from multiple civilizations.
highlights: The magnificent 31-meter central dome that appears to float thanks to hidden windows around its base
Byzantine mosaics including the famous 13th-century Deisis Mosaic showing Christ with the Virgin Mary and John the Baptist
The Apse Mosaic featuring the Virgin Mary with Christ Child, installed in 867
Upper gallery with museum access showcasing centuries of art and history
Norse runic inscriptions on marble walls from Viking mercenaries who served the Byzantine Empire
Ongoing three-year restoration project to protect the structure from earthquakes
tips: Entry fee is 25 euros for tourists (children under 8 free with ID)
Visitors enter through a separate doorway leading to the upper gallery only
Closed to tourists during Friday prayers (12:30-14:30)
Women must wear headscarves; rentals available (scarf 1 euro, body cover 3 euros)
Cover shoulders and knees with modest clothing
Arrive at opening (9:00 AM) or around sunset to avoid crowds and enjoy magical lighting
Allow 60-90 minutes to explore the upper galleries and see the mosaics
Scan QR codes for multilingual audio guide instead of live guided tours
Photography allowed but no flash to avoid disrupting worshippers
vibe: Sacred, monumental, and transcendent. The golden light filtering through windows, the soaring dome overhead, and layers of Byzantine and Ottoman artistry create an atmosphere of timeless grandeur that bridges civilizations and centuries.
expectations: A museum showcasing Byzantine art and architecture
Complete freedom to explore all areas of the building
reality: Now functions as an active mosque with prayer floor reserved for worshippers
Tourist access limited to upper gallery only with 25 euro entry fee
Byzantine mosaics covered during prayer times with special lighting effects
Must observe strict dress code and prayer time closures
unique_facts: The structure has survived 1,500 years and the collapse of two empires
Viking mercenaries carved Norse runic inscriptions into the marble walls in the 9th century
The building has been a church, mosque, museum, and mosque again across its lifetime
April 2025 marked the beginning of a massive restoration project - the most comprehensive in nearly 1,500 years
The dome measures 31 meters across and creates an illusion of floating due to its architectural design
Over 260 windows illuminate the interior with natural light
surprises: The second floor now functions as a museum where you can see the prayer floor from above
You can rent modest clothing at the entrance if you're not dressed appropriately
The building is undergoing its most extensive restoration in 1,500 years
The same structure that once defined Orthodox Christianity now serves as one of Islam's most important mosques
Byzantine Christian mosaics and Islamic calligraphy coexist within the same sacred space
